pros: Encouraging team and leadership. Continuing education is always offered, I have never had to pay out of pocket for CEUs. In our department we have extra leave on top of the agency wide leave so that is very nice.
cons: Working in social work can be stressful at times.

job_title: Family Preservation Specialist in Tulsa, OK
pros: Gained real world experience, supportive mentors
cons: Lots of turnover, high caseload

pros: Great hours, great benefits, positive work environment. Work environment that focuses on finding solutions .
cons: occasional offensive odors - in the elevators (marijuana)

review_title: Great place to work with lots of room for growth
pros: Family and Children's Services is a great place to work for clinicians working to make a difference in their community. You truly make a difference at work - every single day. The agency has LOTS of departments who serve different clientele - from infant mental health to adults with a serious mental illness. From the "worried well" to the most severe, debilitating diagnoses. There is lots of room for growth, both laterally (transferring departments) and upward. They love to promote from within and do a good job noticing and advancing their "Rock Star" employees. And the company is financially robust and growing. I don't ever worry about if we are going to do layoffs due to losing a grant or a funding source... FCS is diversified and was able to still give (nominal) raises when many companies were doing layoffs.
cons: FCS moves at a FAST pace. Fast pace really doesn't even describe it... It's faster than that. Things change quickly and often. So those who thrive here are able to roll with the punches and adjust quickly. So that can be exhausting as an employee - but the one thing that always helps me shift and adjust is that we do ALL THINGS for the betterment of our clients. All decisions are made with them in mind. So when you know the "why" you can adjust your attitude and roll with things.

pros: Since starting at F&CS, I have felt supported by my supervisor and coworkers, I have had many opportunities for training, and feel that my career can really grow here. Applying to F&CS was one of the best career decisions I have ever made!
cons: I believe there are downsides to any job...like having to work period! I don't have any "cons" to list regarding F&CS.

pros: Benefits Creativity Leadership Training Connections
cons: Burnout Timing Resources Networking Promotions

pros: One of the highest paying agencies
cons: Very little training, Workload is high with little to no guidance.

job_title: Licensed Clinical Social Worker LCSW in Tulsa, OK
pros: Benefits and training, support schedule
cons: None I can think of

pros: team members always made days fun
cons: managing style was that of a micromanager

pros: It is a great organization with great benefits.
cons: No cons to report currently.

pros: Responsive, caring management, excellent salary and benefits, with a really generous pto policy and encouragement to use those days, and staffing levels that are reflective of and committed to safety. I also appreciate being of service to many people less fortunate than myself, people that would possibly have nowhere else to turn if we were not here. In addition, we are also committed to diversity and it shows in our employee population.
cons: Only as pertains to being a nurse in a psychiatric facility: you see a lot of the same clients over and over, many of them very psychotic, substance use, etc. Psych nursing is not for everyone!

pros: The benefits are pretty decent.
cons: Not enough training , the workplace is toxic. Employees and clients are not treated well, it's all about the sale and money. They have grown too big and lost sight of their mission.

pros:
Recruiting talented employees
Offering CEUs
Serving the community
cons:
Does not make changes when employees give feedback about things that could improve job satisfaction
Does not provide work/life balance for employees by allowing scheduled time for paperwork, engagement calls, DHS reports, referrals, etc. 
Places employees on discipline contracts for falling more than 20 hours behind on productivity.
Asks clinicians to take on additional responsibilities such as training interns, or new hires without additional compensation
Does not reprimand or remove people in supervisory positions when they are not meeting their job requirements
Asks clinicians to manage caseloads of 100+ clients when the census is high
Upper management does not make an effort to get to know direct level staff

pros:
Salary is competitive and beyond 
Salary is competitive and beyond, Benefits are competitive and then some, Excellent CEU's offered for free throughout the year, Work place facilities are very nice and accommodating. There have been many changes over the last year and all for the better. The leadership team is supportive of their staff and our HR department works to find the best for the agency.
cons: The only con I can think of is I would like to see the agency do more to promote employee activities throughout the year.

pros: Great benefits. Competitive pay. Opportunities for growth within the agency. Open communication with direct leadership. Supported by leadership in growth.
cons: More communication for indirect leadership would be helpful. Change is often made very quickly without time for staff to be able to process the change (even if the change is going to be the best thing for clients and the agency).

pros: Salary is highest around. Benefits are decent, 3 weeks PTO.
cons: 80-120 caseloads. Upper management uses YCCs as a replacement for the revolving door of therapists. They are expected to explain to parents why they have had 3 therapist in 6 months or worse not getting their third or fourth therapist for month because the next round of unsuspecting therapist are being trained. When higher ups schedule mandatory meetings to address the turnover issues they just gaslight everyone working the frontlines and accuse them of being “ Millennials” when they offer real solutions to fix the problems of turnover. You are put in ethical Dilemmas routinely.

pros: Encouraging team and leadership. Continuing education is always offered, I have never had to pay out of pocket for CEUs. In our department we have extra leave on top of the agency wide leave so that is very nice.
cons: Working in social work can be stressful at times.

review_title: A Blessing to Work at F&CS
pros: Support from leadership, encouragement to improve, more time off, salary action/market increase, good people to work with, this agency is trustworthy and genuinely wants to help people
cons: Lots of major changes are draining, they have been necessary but it's difficult getting there

pros: Strong community working department and company, flexible, communicative staff

pros: Decent pay (still doesn’t keep up with the market trends) , good staff.
cons: Enormous caseloads, minimal management support, zero time for paperwork that is required, productivity is emphasized over employee satisfaction & pay is under the market value.

pros: Pay and Benefits Variety or programs to work in
cons: Onboarding training was confusing, however steps have been taken in specific departments to address this issue

pros: It pays some of the bills. There's occasionally cake.
cons: Limited PTO, they don't seem to care about the EMPLOYEE or client mental or physical health, just $$$$$$$$$. That's their focus. Numbers and money. That's all every thing is tied too. Even the "appreciation" events are surface, and seem extremely forced. Play the game, harden your heart, and become conditioned to look the other way a lot, and you can advance. Actually give a rip about fellow humans and you'll be trampled.

review_title: I'm so thankful for this position
pros: I genuinely love my job. I have been with Family and Children's for 4 years and I am still excited to go to work most days. My supervisors have always been amazing supports and my team is incredible. I feel safe to learn and grow here and my program is incredibly flexible. I really appreciate the opportunity for agency trainings and I feel like I am in a place to continually improve as a clinician.
cons: For my current position specifically I can't think of any. In other positions, I could imagine the workloads can be kind of high with limited flexibility in scheduling opportunities. This is also a rather large company and it can be difficult to keep up with all of the programs and know everything that is offered to clients.

review_title: Most organized, supportive environment I have been in
pros: The level of support and training you receive is unparalleled here. It is nice knowing there is always a supervisor available to assist if necessary. Additionally, the company as a whole is well structured and organized and it runs smoothly.
cons: I honestly can not think of one. I get paid well for my position, I have good benefits, good coworkers- I have nothing bad to say, honestly. First job I have ever felt like this.

review_title: Not a bad place to be
pros:
Lots of really friendly coworkers.
With the right position you can get really interesting projects.
Consistent hours.
A predictable pay change with years of experience.
cons:
Some coworkers will not do their job well, and there is nearly nothing that can be done about them.
Sometimes clients will call in angry.

review_title: Great, focused on proving quality services
pros: When changes are needed, they are made.  When support is needed, it is given.  FCS listens to employee needs.
cons: Hire more staff, however they are trying.  Workforce has grown a lot in the last year.

cons: I have no cons to discuss.

review_title: Great pay - did not outweigh job stress
pros:
Salary & benefits are great @ F&CS. 

TF-CBT training is paid for by F&CS.

Direct supervisors (for therapists under supervision) are knowledgeable, kind, compassionate, & helpful.
cons:
7/10 new employees quit in less than 6 months of work there - due to all of the systemic issues & stress involved.

Overall job training was insufficient. 

EHR deleted entire notes multiple times; EHR often froze up completely. 

Computers given for therapy notes would freeze & keyboard would not work properly. 

Billable hours accrued a productivity debt quickly due to lack of organization surrounding referrals.

It is exhausting to work in the school-based department due to systemic issues & the unhealthy work culture created by higher-up management. (not direct supervisors)

pros: You make great relationships and enjoy serving families.

pros: I have worked at F&CS for 4 years. It offers great, paid licensure supervision, great continuing supervision, decent benefits, a large variety of departments and client populations to choose from, easy transitioning within the company, advancement to management positions, competitive pay, and great services for the community. The management work to help employees find their niches and grow each employee in their unique strengths and talents.
cons: As with any mental health field position, the work can be stressful and emotionally draining and it is therefore extremely important to be purposeful in selfcare. F&CS has great ethics and reputation, so we are expected to do our jobs thoroughly and well. Again, this is something we as employees need to learn to manage and can add to the stress for the first year or so of employment. If you are looking to cut corners and do as little as possible, do not apply, but if you want to do your best and become a great therapist, apply!!

pros: A good place to start a career in mental health for therapists, counsellors, or anyone wanting to work with a nonprofit.
cons:
Toxic work environment - the higher up the hierarchy, the worse the treatment. Speaking to HR or management about salary increases, training, highering qualified staff, paying female workers the same as male workers result in frustration for the employee.

Turnover is high - this leads to low morale amongst the staff members, higher workloads for individual staff members and teams, and burnout.

Salaries are too low - cost of living increases are given each year to qualifying staff members. The amount is 3%. Male counterparts have been known to make significantly more than female workers in certain departments.

Poor leadership - management plays favorites and shows gender bias when it comes to promoting staff, giving bonuses, or addressing concerns for staff.

job_title: Mental Health Texh in Tulsa, OK
pros: Learning experience to say the least
cons: Toxic, disorganized managers. No team work. Employees are all scared because someone gets fired every week. The managers are "drunk with power", hostile, backstabbing and unkind. There is no help when you need it and despite being a care facility there is no emphasis on self are which is desperately needed because the consist ions and circumstances of the clients are extremely stressful. The nurse YELLS constantly and is worthless in helping you when you need it. Horrible experience, I was a tech at the crisis care center, it is evident that funding is mismanaged. There were two clients there that both required a wheel chair but has to share the ONE wheel chair the facility has. How is there only one wheel chair...with the huge donations, the yearly White Party and Care Card every year as well as numerous other fund raising ...where is it being used ? Pathetic.

job_title: Orientation Front Desk Attendance Janitorial and Education Department in West Tulsa, OK
pros: The pay getting to greet and better understand the clients request and issues during there tough times and needs.
cons: the time spent at the office and the appointment are not scheduled correctly for the client or individual to make the appointment on that day cause of some other duty or reason there unable to show. Just bad timing of advanced appointments.

review_title: Knowledge of all programs and determining appropriateness for clients seeking services and crisis center overflow calls.
job_title: Call Center Specialist in Tulsa, OK
pros: It is great to help people get set for services and hear how appreciative they are. The call center group is very tight nit and easy going. Excellent benefits for a non profit. This is great job if you love helping people.
cons: It can be stressful and the center is constantly under staffed. Policies and programs change a lot so it is hard to stay on top of the changes. The agency as a whole is over supervised and understaffed.

job_title: Mental Health Technician in Tulsa, OK
pros: Fantastic coworkers with positive attitudes and willing to help. That's really it. Med nurses are nice too. Other than that not much.
cons:
Lazy charge nurses who think helping the techs is below them. 
Management that gives you bones and is upset when you come up with a skeleton. They are surprised when they make you short staffed, and then things get behind when they pull someone off the floor, or someone is covering multiple areas. 
Also, check their websites directly, as they do not list their degree-required jobs on job search websites.

pros: This agency serves a huge percentage of population in the Tulsa area that otherwise would likely be left untreated. It is heartwarming to hear the success stories from Clients.
cons: There is a large issue with control the higher up you go. CEO can be very insulting and very unprofessional. CEO is very smart, but very arrogant. Playing "favorites" is to be expected.

pros: Community connection, work with professionals who really care about their clients, feel as though your work makes a difference
cons: Upper management has lost sight of Agency's mission, staff is not compensated fairly for stressful work environment, more emphasis on "image" than actual work. Poorly planned new EHR system.

pros: Job security, pay check, some of my co-workers, wear Jeans on Friday, free coffee, good location, learned what I won't settle for in my next job
